data.text: be clear/smooth sailing (North American English) (British English be plain sailing)
data.sense: to be simple and free from trouble
easy to see or understand
not clear at all; not easy to understand

examples.text: Oh well, that's all as clear as mud, then.

data.text: clear blue water (between A and B)
data.sense: a complete difference or division between two people or groups

examples.text: Voters want to see clear blue water between the main parties.
They failed to put clear blue water between themselves and their competitors.

data.sense: there is no danger of being seen or caught

examples.text: As soon as the coast was clear, he climbed in through the window.

data.text: keep your head | keep a clear/cool head
data.sense: to remain calm in a difficult situation

examples.text: She needed to keep a clear head if she was to remain in control.

data.text: leave the field clear for somebody
data.sense: to enable somebody to be successful in a particular area of activity because other people or groups have given up competing with them

examples.text: The complete disarray of the opposition parties leaves the field clear for the government to implement urgent reforms.

data.sense: in a way that is very easy to understand

examples.text: The message is coming through loud and clear.

data.text: see your way (clear) to doing something/to do something
data.sense: to find that it is possible or convenient to do something

examples.text: Small builders cannot see their way clear to take on many trainees.
